posts.java: public class Solution {--newline--    public int hammingDistance(int x, int y) {--newline--        return Integer.bitCount(x ^ y);--newline--    }--newline--}--newline--

posts.cpp: class Solution {--newline--public:--newline--    int hammingDistance(int x, int y) {--newline--        int dist = 0, n = x ^ y;--newline--        while (n) {--newline--            ++dist;--newline--            n &= n - 1;--newline--        }--newline--        return dist;--newline--    }--newline--};--newline--
posts.topic_title: My C++ solution using bit manipulation

posts.java: public class Solution {--newline--    public int hammingDistance(int x, int y) {--newline--        int xor = x ^ y, count = 0;--newline--        for (int i=0;i<32;i++) count += (xor >> i) & 1;--newline--        return count;--newline--    }--newline--    --newline--}

posts.cpp: class Solution {--newline--public:--newline--    int hammingDistance(int x, int y) {--newline--        --newline--        int tmpInt=x^y;--newline--        int dis=0;--newline--        --newline--        while(tmpInt)--newline--        {--newline--            if((tmpInt>>1)<<1 != tmpInt)--newline--            {--newline--                ++dis;--newline--            }--newline--            --newline--            tmpInt>>=1;--newline--        }--newline--        --newline--        return dis;--newline--    }--newline--    --newline--}
